{{Infobox sports season | title = 2009 Pacific-10 Conference football season | caption = #193980 | color = #193980 | color text = white | league = [[NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I FBS (Football Bowl Subdivision)]] | sport = [[College football|football]] | logo = Pacific-10 Conference logo.png | pixels = 125px | caption = | duration = September 3, 2009
through January 1, 2010 | no_of_teams = 10 | attendance = | TV = | draft = | draft_link = | top_pick = | picked_by = | season = Regular Season | season_champs = [[2009 Oregon Ducks football team|Oregon Ducks]] | season_champ_name= Champion | league_champs = | league_champ_name= Runners-Up | second_place = [[2009 Stanford Cardinal football team|Stanford Cardinal]]
[[2009 Arizona Wildcats football team|Arizona Wildcats]]
[[2009 Oregon State Beavers football team|Oregon State Beavers]] | MVP = | MVP_link = | top_scorer = | top_scorer_link = | promote = | promoted_from = | relegate = | relegate_to = | playoffs = | playoffs_link = | conf1 = | conf1_link = | conf1_champ = | conf1-runner-up = | conf2 = | conf2_link = | conf2_champ = | conf2-runner-up = | playoffs_MVP = | playoffs_MVP_link= | finals = | finals_link = | finals_champ = | finals_runner-up = | finals_MVP = | finals_MVP_link = | seasonslist = | seasonslistnames = Football | prevseason_year = [[2008 Pacific-10 Conference football season|2008]] | nextseason_year = [[2010 Pacific-10 Conference football season|2010]] }} {{2009 Pacific-10 football standings}} The '''2009 [[Pacific-10 Conference]] football season''' started on Thursday, September 3, 2009. [[2009 Oregon Ducks football team|Oregon]] won the Pac-10 title, which had been held by [[2009 USC Trojans football team|USC]] for the past seven years. Seven conference teams were invited to participate in post season bowl games, with only [[2009 UCLA Bruins football team|UCLA]] and [[2009 USC Trojans football team|USC]] winning their bowl games. ==Previous season== During the [[2008 NCAA Division I FBS football season]], all five Pac-10 teams won their bowl games: * [[2009 Rose Bowl|Rose Bowl]] - [[2008 USC Trojans football team|USC]] 38, [[2008 Penn State Nittany Lions football team|Penn State]] 24 * [[2008 Holiday Bowl|Holiday Bowl]] - [[2008 Oregon Ducks football team|Oregon]] 42, [[2008 Oklahoma State Cowboys football team|Oklahoma]] State 31 * [[2008 Sun Bowl|Sun Bowl]] - [[2008 Oregon State Beavers football team|Oregon State]] 3, [[2008 Pittsburgh Panthers football team|Pittsburgh]] 0 * [[2008 Emerald Bowl|Emerald Bowl]] - [[2008 California Golden Bears football team|California]] 24, [[2008 Miami Hurricanes football team|Miami]] 17 * [[2008 Las Vegas Bowl|Las Vegas Bowl]] - [[2008 Arizona Wildcats football team|Arizona]] 31, [[2008 BYU Cougars football team|BYU]] 21 ==Preseason== Pre-season poll voted on by the media during the Pacific-10 Football Media Day, with the number of first-place votes shown in parentheses:[http://www.uclabruins.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/073009aab.html Bruins Picked To Finish Seventh In Pac-10 Conference Football], ''UCLABruins.com'', July 30, 2009 # [[2009 USC Trojans football team|USC]] (28) # [[2009 California Golden Bears football team|California]] (3) # [[2009 Oregon Ducks football team|Oregon]] (1) # [[2009 Oregon State Beavers football team|Oregon State]] # [[2009 Arizona State Sun Devils football team|Arizona State]] # [[2009 Stanford Cardinal football team|Stanford]] # [[2009 UCLA Bruins football team|UCLA]] # [[2009 Arizona Wildcats football team|Arizona]] # [[2009 Washington Huskies football team|Washington]] # [[2009 Washington State Cougars football team|Washington State]] ==Rankings== {{See|2009 NCAA Division I FBS football rankings}} ==Highlights== ===September=== * September 3, 2009 â In the first game of the season for both teams, #14 [[2009 Oregon Ducks football team|Oregon]] was upset by #16 [[2009 Boise State Broncos football team|Boise State]], 19-8. * September 12, 2009 â UCLA defeated [[2009 Tennessee Volunteers football team|Tennessee]], 19-15, before a crowd of 102,239 at [[Neyland Stadium]]. A last-minute Volunteers drive was stopped by the Bruins at the goal line. * September 12, 2009 â With 1:05 left, USC's [[Stafon Johnson]] scored on a 2-yard run for a touchdown to give the [[2009 USC Trojans football team|Trojans]] a 18-15 win over [[2009 Ohio State Buckeyes football team|Ohio State]] in front of a record 106,033 fans in [[Columbus, Ohio|Columbus]]. * September 19, 2009 â The unranked [[2009 Washington Huskies football team|Washington]] upset #3 ranked [[2009 USC Trojans football team|USC]] 16-13 in Seattle after [[Erik Folk]] scored the winning field goal. The Huskies would be ranked 25th the following day. * September 26, 2009 â [[2009 Oregon Ducks football team|Oregon]] pulled an upset of #6 ranked [[2009 California Golden Bears football team|California]], 42-3 at [[Autzen Stadium]]. ===October=== * October 3, 2009 â [[2009 Stanford Cardinal football team|Stanford]] ended [[2009 UCLA Bruins football team|UCLA]]'s unbeaten record, winning 24-18 at Stanford; [[2009 California Golden Bears football team|California]] lost their second conference game, 30-3 to [[2009 USC Trojans football team|USC]]; [[2009 Oregon Ducks football team|Oregon]] won their fourth in a row with a 52-6 victory over [[2009 Washington State Cougars football team|Washington State]]. * October 10, 2009 â [[2009 Oregon Ducks football team|Oregon]] won its fifth consecutive game, 24-10 over [[2009 UCLA Bruins football team|UCLA]]; [[2009 Stanford Cardinal football team|Stanford]] lost its first conference game, 38-28 to [[2009 Oregon State Beavers football team|Oregon State]] at [[Reser Stadium]], [[Corvallis, Oregon|Corvallis]]. * October 17, 2009 â California won its first conference game against UCLA, the first win for the Bears in Southern California during [[Jeff Tedford]]'s tenure as head coach. Cal had previously been 0-7 on the road against USC and UCLA. * October 17, 2009 â USC held off [[2009 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|Notre Dame]] for their eighth consecutive win over the Fighting Irish, 34-27. * October 24, 2009 â The week's Pac-10 game of the week featured Oregon State against USC. The Beavers had the longest road winning streak at five games and had beaten the Trojans twice in their previous three meetings. USC had won 46 of the last 47 home games, not allowing more than 10 points at the [[Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum|Coliseum]] since mid 2007, and had surrendered a total of 38 points during the last ten home games. The Trojans managed to hold off the Beavers and win 42-36. * October 31, 2009 â The [[Halloween Day|Halloween]] match-up between USC (BCS No. 5) and Oregon (BCS No. 10) could determine the conference champion. USC had lost three in a row in the state of Oregon prior to the game.Gary Klein, [http://www.latimes.com/sports/college/usc/la-sp-usc-pete-carroll30-2009oct30,0,1828252.story It's a big game for Trojans -- and Pete Carroll], ''Los Angeles Times'', October 30, 2009 ESPN's [[College Gameday (football)|College Gameday]] broadcast from [[Eugene, OR|Eugene]]. The Ducks won, 47-20, to stay on top of the conference standings. The defeat was the worst in the [[Pete Carroll]] era, giving up the most points and by the largest margin.Scott Wolf, [http://www.dailynews.com/sports/ci_13688380 USC back on the Oregon fail], ''Los Angeles Daily News'', November 1, 2009 * October 31, 2009 â With 21 seconds left in the game, Giorgio Tavecchio kicked a 24-yard field goal to give California a comeback victory over [[2009 Arizona State Sun Devils football team|Arizona State]], 23-21.[http://www.calbears.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/103109aaa.html Cal Rallies to Get 23-21 Victory Over Arizona State], ''CALBears.com'', October 31, 2009 * October 31, 2009 â Behind 19-3 in the fourth quarter, UCLA rallied back with two passing touchdowns and two two-point conversions to tie the game against Oregon State. [[James Rodgers (football)|James Rodgers]] scored for the [[2009 Oregon State Beavers football team|Beavers]] in less than two minutes to pull out a win at home, 26-19.[http://www.osubeavers.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/103109aab.html Beavers pull out thriller, 26-19], ''OSUBeavers.com'', October 31, 2009 ===November=== * November 7, 2009 - #7 Oregon's undefeated conference season came to an end at [[2009 Stanford Cardinal football team|Stanford]], being upset 51-42. Stanford became bowl-eligible for the first time since 2001 and earned a Top 25 ranking at #25. Running back [[Toby Gerhart]] ran for a school record 223 yards. Both teams have five victories in the Pac-10 championship race. * November 7, 2009 - Oregon State upsets #23 California, with the Bears' last home victory against the Beavers being in 1997. * November 14, 2009 - With the conference wide open, [[Toby Gerhart]] and the #25 Stanford Cardinal pulled their second upset in a row with a 55-21 road victory over #11 USC, the most points ever surrendered by the Trojans. USC has lost three of five at home to Stanford during the last ten years (2001, 2007, and 2009). * November 14, 2009 - Oregon State defeated Washington, 48-21, to stay in the hunt for the conference championship. * November 14, 2009 - California hung on to upset #18 Arizona 24-16 in the Golden Bears' final home season game. * November 14, 2009 - With UCLA's 43-7 win over Washington State and Oregon's 44-21 win over Arizona State, four teams scored over 40 points. * November 21, 2009 - #11 Oregon at Arizona was the game-of-the-week, with both teams playing for a trip to the [[2010 Rose Bowl|Rose Bowl]] on New Year's Day. Arizona has never been to the Rose Bowl while Oregon has not been there since the [[1995 Rose Bowl|1994 season]]. In double overtime, Oregon came back to win the game 44-41. * November 21, 2009 - #25 California upsets #17 Stanford in the 112th Big Game 34-28 to retain possession of the [[Stanford Axe]], ending the Cardinal's Rose Bowl hopes. Stanford had scored 106 points in its past two games in victories over Oregon and USC. * November 21, 2009 - #19 Oregon State defeats Washington State 42-10 to set up a head to head matchup against Oregon in the [[Civil War (college football game)|Civil War]] to decide the conference champion. * November 28, 2009 - [[College rivalry|Rivalry]] Week: [[UCLAâUSC rivalry|UCLA vs. USC]], [[Apple Cup|WSU vs. Washington]], [[Territorial Cup|ASU vs. Arizona]]. The winners were Arizona 20-17, Washington 30-0, and USC 28-7. * November 28, 2009 - Stanford rallied to defeat [[2009 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|Notre Dame]] for the first time since 2001, 45-38. ===December=== * December 3, 2009 - Oregon defeats Oregon State 37-33 in the [[Civil War (college football game)|Civil War]] to claim the conference championship and earn a spot in the [[2010 Rose Bowl]] against [[2009 Ohio State Buckeyes football team|Ohio State]], Oregon's first trip since the [[1995 Rose Bowl]]. * December 5, 2009 - With Arizona defeating #20 USC 21-17, Arizona State became the only school in the Pac-10 that has not beaten the Trojans at least once during the Pete Carroll era. * December 5, 2009 - Washington upsets #19 California 42-10, becoming the eleventh [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|FBS]] team since 1946 to follow a winless [[2008 Washington Huskies football team|2008 season]] with five victories. * December 12, 2009 â [[2009 Army Black Knights football team|Army]] fell short of bowl eligibility by losing 17-3 in the [[Army-Navy game]] to allow UCLA to go to the [[2009 EagleBank Bowl|EagleBank Bowl]], scheduled for December 29, 2009. ==Notes== * September 3 - [[2009 Oregon Ducks football team|Oregon]] running back [[LeGarrette Blount]] was suspended by the university for the season after he punched [[2009 Boise State Broncos football team|Boise State]] defensive end [[Byron Hout]] in the chin after Hout had taunted him in front of Boise State head coach [[Chris Petersen]] at the end of their season opening game.{{cite web|url=http://blog.oregonlive.com/behindducksbeat/2009/09/oregons_legarrette_blount_susp.html|publisher=[[The Oregonian]]|author=John Hunt|title=Oregon's LaGarrette Blount suspended for season|date=2009-09-04|accessdate=2009-09-04}} Blount was reinstated on November 9, 2009 with the approval of the conference. * September 28 - A weight room accident ended [[2009 USC Trojans football team|USC]] tailback [[Stafon Johnson]]'s season.Gary Klein and Ben Bolch, [http://www.latimes.com/sports/la-sp-stafon-johnson-usc29-2009sep29,0,3244790.story USC running back Stafon Johnson hurt in weight-room accident], ''Los Angeles Times'', September 29, 2009 * The Pac-10 will use football stars in a new promotion: California's [[Aaron Rodgers]]; Oregon's [[Joey Harrington]]; Oregon State's [[Mike Riley]] (coach); Southern California's [[Pete Carroll]] (coach), [[Marcus Allen]], and [[Carson Palmer]]; Washington's [[Warren Moon]]; and Washington State's [[Drew Bledsoe]]. * The media's only correct pre-season prediction was on Washington State. * December 12 - Stanford running back [[Toby Gerhart]] finishes second to [[2009 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|Alabama]] running back [[Mark Ingram, Jr.]] in the closest vote in [[Heisman Trophy]] history. * December 17 - It was reported that [[Joe McKnight]], USC tailback, may have violated [[NCAA]] rules by driving a sport utility vehicle owned by a Santa Monica businessman. * January 1, 2010 - With [[2009 Oregon Ducks football team|Oregon]]'s loss to [[2009 Ohio State Buckeyes football team|Ohio State]] in the [[2010 Rose Bowl|Rose Bowl]], the Pac-10's bowl record for the 2009 season was 2-5. The previous season all five Pac-10 teams to receive bowl bids won their bowl games. * January 10, 2010 â USC head coach [[Pete Carroll]] told his players that he will resign his position with the Trojans and become the new head coach of the [[Seattle Seahawks]].Dan Loumena, [http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/sports_blog/2010/01/pete-carroll-to-take-seattle-seahawks-coaching-position.html Pete Carroll to take Seattle Seahawks coaching position], ''Los Angeles Times'', January 10, 2010 * January 13, 2010 â [[Tennessee Volunteers football|Tennessee]] head coach [[Lane Kiffin]] was named the new head coach of the Trojans. He had been an assistant coach at USC from 2001-2006 under Pete Carroll, including a stint as offensive coordinator. * January 25, 2010 â California announced a $321 million retrofit of [[California Memorial Stadium|Memorial Stadium]] to begin in June. * February 18, 2010 â Cal's defensive coordinator Bob Gregory left for [[Boise State football|Boise State]] and was replaced by [[Clancy Pendergast]], former defensive coordinator for the [[Oakland Raiders]].Associated Press, [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2010/02/20/SPI51C3QFR.DTL Cal hires Raiders' coach away after one week], ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', February 20, 2010 Stanford replaced defensive coordinator Ron Lynn with [[Vic Fangio]], who had formerly been with the [[Baltimore Ravens]]. Former [[Chicago Bears]] offensive coordinator [[Ron Turner (American football)|Ron Turner]] will be quarterbacks and wide receivers coach and former [[Minnesota Vikings]] assistant [[Derek Mason]] will be the defensive backs coach at Stanford.Associated Press , [http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=4922490 Stanford hires two assistants], ''[[ESPN]]'', February 17, 2020 * February 21, 2010 â At Oregon, [[LaMichael James]] was arrested on February 17 and pleaded not guilty to charges of fourth-degree assault, physical harassment and strangulation. Oregon kicker Rob Beard and defensive end Matt Simms were cited for misdemeanor assault investigation. Simms was dismissed from the team and kicker Mike Bowlin left the team. Simms and Beard have pleaded not guilty. Jamere Holland was dismissed from the Oregon football team for his Facebook comments.Associated Press, [http://www.dailynews.com/sports/ci_14446559 Former Taft High, USC receiver Holland dismissed from Oregon football team], ''Los Angeles Daily News'', February 21, 2010 * April 22, 2010 - Cal defensive end [[Tyson Alualu]] and running back [[Jahvid Best]] were selected as the 10th and 30th overall picks in the [[2010 NFL Draft]], respectively. They were the only Pac-10 players to be drafted in the first round. This also marked the first time since 2003 that two Cal players had been drafted in the first round of the NFL Draft.{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2010/04/23/SPQ71D34AN.DTL|title=Lineman Alualu, Best give the Bears 2 first-rounders |date=2010-04-23|last=Crumpacker|first=John|accessdate=2010-04-23|publisher=SFGate.com}} * April 22-24, 2010 - Twenty eight players were selected in In the 2010 NFL draft. USC had the most players selected, with seven. Arizona State had four, California, Oregon, Stanford, and UCLA each had three, Arizona and Washington had two each, and Oregon State had one player selected. No players from Washington State were drafted. ==Players-of-the-week== [[File:Cal at UCLA 09.jpg|thumb|250px|Cal's Shane Vereen (no. 34) takes the handoff from [[Kevin Riley]] (no. 13) at the Cal-UCLA game]] {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! rowspan="2" | Week ! colspan="2" | Offensive ! colspan="2" | Defensive ! colspan="2" | Special teams |- !
